results.title: Andrew Garfield Can’t Remember Who He Was Before ‘Tick, Tick … Boom!’
results.abstract: In the movie musical, Garfield plays the creator of “Rent,” who died unexpectedly at 35. Making the film helped Garfield process a death in his own life.

multimedia.caption: “Tick, Tick … Boom” is about Jonathan Larson, who created “Rent.” To Andrew Garfield, “every frame, every moment, every breath of this film is an attempted honoring of Jon. And, on a more personal level, it’s an honoring of my mom.”
multimedia.copyright: Alana Paterson for The New York Times

multimedia.caption: “Tick, Tick … Boom” is about Jonathan Larson, who created “Rent.” To Andrew Garfield, “every frame, every moment, every breath of this film is an attempted honoring of Jon. And, on a more personal level, it’s an honoring of my mom.”
multimedia.copyright: Alana Paterson for The New York Times

multimedia.copyright: Alana Paterson for The New York Times

results.title: Halle Berry’s Fight for the Director’s Chair
results.abstract: In many ways, her new film “Bruised” lets her assert control over how she appears onscreen. But first she had to win the job.

multimedia.caption: Halle Berry in Los Angeles. Directing “Bruised,” she said, let her “feel powerful just because I get to do it and put my voice in the world.”

results.title: Our Film Critics Discuss the Future of Movies
results.abstract: Taking a look at the new season in the new abnormal, while remembering the lessons of cinema history. Are we on the cusp of a new era or will this too pass?
results.byline: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott

results.title: The Rich History of Black Westerns Enters a New Era
results.abstract: The genre dates back decades, when the films were made for segregated audiences. “The Harder They Fall” nods to the past but takes a new attitude altogether.

multimedia.caption: Danielle Deadwyler, left, Jonathan Majors and Zazie Beetz in “The Harder They Fall.”
Danielle Deadwyler, left, Jonathan Majors and Zazie Beetz in “The Harder They Fall.”
Danielle Deadwyler, left, Jonathan Majors and Zazie Beetz in “The Harder They Fall.”
Danielle Deadwyler, left, Jonathan Majors and Zazie Beetz in “The Harder They Fall.”
Danielle Deadwyler, left, Jonathan Majors and Zazie Beetz in “The Harder They Fall.”

results.title: How Lauren Ridloff’s Deafness Became a Superpower in Marvel’s ‘Eternals’
results.abstract: In her first major role in a feature film, she wasn’t fazed by things that might unnerve others, but she had to show filmmakers how to work with deafness.

multimedia.caption: Lauren Ridloff said that being cast in “Eternals” meant “my two boys, who are also deaf, will grow up in a world where there are superheroes who are deaf.”
multimedia.copyright: Amy Harrity for The New York Times

results.title: When Wes Anderson Comes to Town, Buildings Get Symmetrical
results.abstract: For “The French Dispatch,” the filmmakers set up shop in a real French city to create the setting for the movie’s fictional one.

multimedia.caption: The French Dispatch building in Wes Anderson’s film. The shot uses a combination of real exteriors in Angoulême, a town in southwest France, and miniatures to achieve its look.

results.title: There’s Always Been More to Kirsten Dunst

results.title: Pauli Murray Should Be a Household Name. A New Film Shows Why.
results.abstract: The lawyer, activist and minister made prescient arguments on gender, race and equality that influenced Thurgood Marshall and Ruth Bader Ginsburg.

multimedia.caption: A scene from “My Name Is Pauli Murray.” The documentarian Betsy West, who made the film with Julie Cohen, said, “We just thought, why didn’t anybody teach us about this person?”

results.title: Art Metrano, Actor and Comic Once Felled by an Accident, Dies at 84
results.abstract: He had built a career in stand-up comedy and in film and TV, but a fall from a ladder left him with a personal struggle.

multimedia.caption: The actor Art Metrano in the 1980s. His career was interrupted by an accident in 1989. “When you’re lying paralyzed in a hospital bed,” he said during a subsequent stage show, “your past becomes your constant companion because your future is a question mark.”

The actor Art Metrano in the 1980s. His career was interrupted by an accident in 1989. “When you’re lying paralyzed in a hospital bed,” he said during a subsequent stage show, “your past becomes your constant companion because your future is a question mark.”

results.title: Kaycee Moore, Actress in Black Directors’ Seminal Films, Dies at 77
results.abstract: She explored her characters’ inner lives in movies like “Killer of Sheep” and “Bless Their Little Hearts,” independent works that grew out of the L.A. Rebellion movement.

multimedia.caption: Kaycee Moore in the film “Killer of Sheep,” in which she played the wife of a slaughterhouse worker as she struggles to raise a family in the Watts section of Los Angeles. She made only a handful of movies, but they had an outsize impact on American cinema.

Kaycee Moore in the film “Killer of Sheep,” in which she played the wife of a slaughterhouse worker as she struggles to raise a family in the Watts section of Los Angeles. She made only a handful of movies, but they had an outsize impact on American cinema.

results.title: Nino Castelnuovo, ‘The Umbrellas of Cherbourg’ Star, Dies at 84
results.abstract: Mr. Castelnuovo, who brought an incandescent charm to the screen, became famous during a golden age of Italian cinema. But his breakthrough role was in a French film.

multimedia.caption: Nino Castelnuovo secured his place in the international film canon for his performance opposite Catherine Deneuve in Jacques Demy’s 1964 musical, “The Umbrellas of Cherbourg.”
